comments.commentBody: Gotta question that. Have you read the book? This was very much the cultural vision of a bourgeois, Victor Hugo, "the French Dickens." It is poverty filtered, tamed, and idealized for middle class audiences who, if they were to empathize with the poor, had to be presented with an idealized vision of poverty that fit neatly within their own value system.

It's worth noting that when the musical itself originally premiered, it was panned by the critics as the worst trite many had ever seen. Although I appreciate the technical application of Irony given here, I don't think that is the true source of critical disdain for Les Miserables; that seems more like a movie genre issue while critical disdain of Les Miserables goes back to the stage.

Rather, I'd couch it in terms of how Les Miserables is a role reversal between experts and the general population. As a story, Les Miserables is meant to convey a cultural experience about a very specific time period in France. That cultural experience was had by the larger population, and it was greatly defined by a small group of privileged "bourgeois" being so disconnected from that cultural experience. Normally, the general population defers to an expert to deliver insights and understanding on a given topic. But Les Miserables is a powerful invocation of the cultural experience of the masses not just offering itself to disconnected experts and nobles, but practically demanding that it be understood. Not allowing intellectual distance, confronting us with raw and open emotional pleas, leaning on simpler themes that cannot be misunderstood or reinterpreted: these are all devices for commanding a certain unity in experience ("the event" in marxist terms). Finding this role reversal abrasive seems the underlying source of the critic's hatred to me.

While I agree that irony is the prevailing trope in much of popular cinema, I disagree that it is the flaw in this particular film.  The fault in the film is not its lack of irony, but rather its lack of subtlety.  Hooper's directorial decisions (the aforementioned live singing and close-ups) only enhance the melodrama inherent in the source material rather than temper it.  This is work which caricatures its two overriding themes -- passion (red) and death (black) -- without probing them.  It is pure narrative without significance.  The archetypal stories reflected in the plot 1) obsessive pursuit, 2) tragic love and 3) redemption are rendered trite in this telling without character development or motive to inform them.   This film (and the musical before it) exist solely to stir emotion and not communicate a perspective on the events described and that is the source of the critical animosity.  It is the cinematic equivalent of Diet Coke - a saccharine substitute for the real thing, which itself is only empty calories.
